summary: bocavirus (hBoV) is a viral agent that belongs to the family Parvoviridae. it contains a single linear positive-sense or negative-sense single-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid genome. this virus has been detected mainly in younger children, in nasopharyngeal secretions, in sera and blood samples of patients with upper (URTI) and lower (LRTI) respiratory tract infections. nasopharyngeal secretions were collected from children attending the emergency room of the Fondazione IRCCS Ca’ Granda Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico, Milan, Italy. the study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the Fondazione IRCCS Ca’ Granda Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico, University of Milan, Italy. patients were classified into disease groups (i.e., acute otitis media, rhinosinusitis, pha the extract was tested for respiratory viruses using the respiratory virus panel xTAG RVP FAST v2 (Luminex Molecular Diagnostics, Inc., Toronto, Canada) it simultaneously detects influenza A virus (subtypes H1 or H3); influenza B virus; respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) types A and B; human parainfluenza virus types 1–4 (hPiV1-4); adenovirus (AdV); human metapneumovirus (hMP each 25 L singleplex reaction mixture consisted of 0.5 L of forward primer 5’-TGCAGACAACGCYTAGTTGTTT-3’ and reverse primer 5’-CTGTCCCGCCCAAGATACA-3’. PCRs were conducted at 50°C for 2 min and then at 95°C for 10 min, followed by 45 cycles at 95°C for 15 sec and at 60°C for 1 min. spectrophotometer (NanoDrop products, Wilmington, DE, USA) each run included plasmid and negative controls. negative controls were included in every PCR assay. quantitative results were reported as DNA copies/mL of respiratory samples. phylogenetic trees of the hBoV VP-1/2 protein gene were generated using the neighbour-joining method and p-distance model of the Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analyses (MEGA) software. the graphs were made using GraphPad Prism version 5.01 for Windows (GraphPAD Software, San Diego, CA) EL and MEME p-values of 0.1 and a FUBAR posterior probability of >0.90 were accepted as candidates for selection. categorical variables were presented as mean values and standard deviations (SDs) for categorical data, comparisons between groups were performed using a contingency table analysis. patients were classified into disease groups on the basis of signs and/or symptoms using well-established criteria. they were finally subdivided into two subgroups: upper (URTIs) and lower respiratory tract infections (LRTIs) amplification and detection of viral DNA were performed with a 7900HT real-time PCR System machine (Applied Biosystems, California, USA) each 25 L singleplex reaction mixture consisted of 0.5 L of forward primer 5’-TGCAGACAACGCYTAGTTGTTT-3’ and reverse primer 5’-CTGTCCCGCCCAAGATACA-3’ for the 88 base pair NS-1 target. each run included one synthetic template control and one no-template control for each target. specimen extracts were also tested by real-time PCR for the human RNase-P gene. sequence analysis performed on a 3130 Genetic Analyser. phylogenetic trees of the VP-1/2 gene were generated using the neighbour-joining method and p-distance model of the Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analyses. the SLAC approach counts the ratios of non-synonymous to synonymous changes per non-synonymous site (dS) sites with SLAC, FEL, IFEL and MEME p-values of 0.1 and a posterior probability of >0.90 were accepted as candidates for selection. 1,823 nasopharyngeal samples were collected in the emergency room. of these, 104 (5.7%) tested positive for hBoV. HBoV was the only virus detected in 57/104 (54.8%) cases. p-value = 0.03 for comparison between subgroups of presence of co-infection(s) according to age group. all of the Italian hBoV strains detected during the three study periods belonged to hBoV genotype 1. a total of 61/672 amino acid positions were observed to have at least one change in the VP1/VP2 sequence alignments. of these, 7/61 (11.5%) changes occurred within the VP1 unique (VP1U) region corresponding to the first 129 amino acids at the N-terminus of the VP1 gene. hBoV st1 strains had 13 and 14 amino acid changes compared to the hBoV st1 strain. the origin of this highly divergent region, which occurred in spite of the conservation displayed in the rest of hBoV DNA genome, remains to be defined. a wide range of hBoV DNA levels from 3.5x102 to 7.5x109 copies/mL were found in the clinical samples. a total of 16 strains had a very high viral load, and 13/16 (81.3%) harboured the T590S mutation. frequency (42/70; 53.8%) of T590S in the group of strains described below (p = 0.08) seven of the 13 strains with the T590S mutation had an additional mutation in one of the sites under positive selection. we hypothesize that the double mutation of N546H with T590S may positively affect viral replication and specific immune response. children infected with only hBoV-1 had URTIs more frequently than those with a co-infection. a similar illness in the family in the 7 days since patient enrolment was significantly more common among co-infected children than among those with a single infection. clinical findings Cough 41/49 (83.7) 39/47 (83.0) 0.93 Rhonchi 2/49 (4.1) 4/47 (8.5) 0.43 Rales 15/49 (30.6) 15/47 (31.9) 0.89 Wheezes 7/49 (14.3) 9/47 (19.1) 0.52 Upper respiratory tract infection 17/46 (37.0) 8/45 (17.8) 0.04 Lower respiratory tract infection 25/55 (45.4) 24/46 (52.2) 0.50 Clinical outcome Hospitalisation rate, b 0.7 0.6 0.6 0.8 0.88 CRP, g/dL 6.2 15.4 1.4 2.2 0.32 CRP: C reactive protein; (51.1) 31 (47.0) 25 (65.8) 3 18 (17.3) 13 (22.8 97.8–100% between the italian strains and 98.4–99.7% with respect to hBoV st1 reference strains. the remaining strains had at least three amino acid changes. a total of 61/672 (9.1%) amino acid positions were observed to have at least one change in the sequence alignments. the VP1U region includes the conserved phospholipase A2 motif (nt 21–63) the amino acid residues at positions 21, 41, 42 and 63 have been hypothesized to form the catalytic network for enzymatic activity. in our hBoV strains, all the sequences had amino acids associated with efficient enzymatic activity. selected codons (411 and 546) were identified. the selected sites were located in the external loop of the VP1 or VP2 protein. the ala (A) to Ser mutation was observed at codon 411. a wide range of hBoV DNA levels from 3.5x102 to 7.5x109 copies/mL were found in the clinical samples. in the group of strains (n = 70; 66.6%) harbouring at least 2 mutations in addition to A149T, the values of the hBoV load greater than 1x108 DNA copies/ml are reported in grey. acid changes were observed with viral loads lower than 106 DNA copies/mL. this could suggest that these mutations do not confer a replicative advantage in these virus strains. comparisons between subjects positive for human bocavirus with or without co-infection(s) N = 48 P value for comparison Laboratory data White blood cell count (cells/L), °39.0°C or more any time during the illness. all of the strains detected in this study belonged to hBoV genotype 1. this genotype is the most common among hBoVs associated with respiratory infections. more than 50% of children infected with hBoV1 were co-infected with at least one other respiratory virus. studies on children with severe pneumonia, acute wheezing, asthma and/or bronchiolitis suggested that hBoV1 is able to infect the lower airways down to the bronchioles. hBoV1 has been found as the only infectious agent in adult lung transplant recipients with severe LRTI, whereas it was not detected in respiratory secretions of asymptomatic transplanted subjects. the importance of hBoV1 concerns the correlation between viral load levels and the presence of specific mutations. a double mutant (N546H and T590S) was observed in samples with a significantly higher viral load. however, further phenotypic validation studies are required to draw major conclusions. strains identified in respiratory samples collected in January 2014 had unusual amino acid sequences in a somewhat conserved genomic region. hBoV is less common than other respiratory viruses but that the frequency of its detection in children with respiratory disease is in time stable. the viral load was not associated with clinical characteristics of the infection. viral mutations, despite affecting viral replication, did not affect the conditions or severity of the clinical presentation. further studies are needed to clarify the clinical relevance of hBoV in children.
